values: I'm writing regarding the current redundancy process - it's unfair and I'm seeking a resolution.
I am writing regarding the current redundancy process. This process is unfair and I am seeking a resolution. [The reasons the process is unfair can be summarised as follows.]
I'm writing further to my recent resignation.
I'm writing further to my recent resignation, which [as you're aware] was due to [add reason].
I refer to my suspension which was unjustified.
I refer to my suspension from work on [date] [and the ongoing [disciplinary / performance] (delete as appropriate) process], which I consider to be unjustified and unlawful.
Following my recent dismissal, I'm writing to express serious concerns.
I refer to my recent unfair dismissal.
I'm writing in respect of unlawful treatment I suffered at work.

I'm writing in respect of unlawful treatment that I have suffered at work[, including LIST TYPES OF TREATMENT].  [I am also entitled to bring claims for [LIST TYPES OF CLAIMS, E.G. DISCRIMINATION, WHISTLEBLOWING, UNLAWFUL DEDUCTIONS OF WAGES.]

I have felt bullied by the following actions.

[provide up to 3 bullet points of strong, recent examples - try to keep them within the last 2-3 months, if possible].
This was part of a sustained campaign of humiliation, professional undermining and bullying.

I felt bullied by the following actions.

[provide up to 3 bullet points of strong, recent examples - try to keep them within the last 2-3 months, if possible].
E, R, C, H, W, B
You failed your health & safety duty - coronavirus unsafe workplace.

You failed your duty in respect of health and safety. I’m being asked to attend a workplace that is unsafe due to coronavirus. I could work from home, but I’m not being allowed. I’m regularly being called into meetings in the office that are either unecessary or could be conducted remotely. As you'll be aware, you have a duty at common law and under Section 2(1) of the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 to “ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, the health, safety and welfare at work of all his employees”.

Second, you failed your duty in respect of health and safety. I’m being asked to attend a workplace that is unsafe due to coronavirus. I could work from home, but I’m not being allowed. I’m regularly being called into meetings in the office that are either unecessary or could be conducted remotely. I’ve been subjected to detrimental treatment in respect of my health and safety, which is a violation of s.44 and potentially of s.100 of the Employment Rights Act 1996.
I am prepared to present an employment tribunal claim for discrimination.

I am prepared to present an employment tribunal claim. The discriminatory treatment has caused extreme upset [and negatively affected my mental health], which justifies a substantial award for injury to feelings.
I've been subjected to unlawful discrimination.

I’ve been subjected to unlawful [insert protected characteristic(s)] discrimination. 

[provide up to 3 bullet points of strong, recent examples - try to keep them within the last 2-3 months, if possible].
I was subjected to unlawful discrimination.

I was subjected to unlawful [insert protected characteristic(s)] discrimination.

[provide up to 3 bullet points of strong, recent examples - try to keep them within the last 2-3 months, if possible].

I’ve been subjected to [protected characteristic(s)] harassment and/or direct discrimination.

[provide up to 3 bullet points of strong, recent examples - try to keep them within the last 2-3 months, if possible].

I was subjected to [protected characteristic(s)] harassment and/or direct discrimination.

[provide up to 3 bullet points of strong, recent examples - try to keep them within the last 2-3 months, if possible].
It's clear that my treatment was discriminatory.

It’s clear that my treatment was due to my [protected characteristic(s)] because:

[Explain why. Remember it’s not always obvious why the treatment is discriminatory, however bad it is. Always compare to how someone else of a different sex, race etc was/would have been treated. Aim to explain the discriminatory reason(s) as clearly as possible.

E.g. ‘There were three of us who lost office keys. I was the only female and the only one disciplined. The two male colleagues didn’t face any consequences.’

NB: you don’t need this paragraph if the examples of bad treatment you provided in the previous paragraph are self-explanatory, e.g. racist or sexist jokes. If in doubt, do include this paragraph.]
Your actions had a discriminatory motive as there is no rational explanation to such appalling treatment.

Your actions were motivated by my [insert protected characteristic] as there is no rational explanation to such appalling treatment.

[USE THIS PARAGRAPH IF YOU IT'S NOT POSSIBLE TO GIVE CLEAR REASONS FOR WHY THE TREATMENT WAS DISCRIMINATORY.]
Your seemingly neutral practice has discriminated against me indirectly.

Your practice of [explain the practice] has placed me at a disadvantage because of my [insert relevant protected characteristic]. This is unlawful indirect discrimination.

[Add facts, explaining how the employer’s seemingly neutral policy or practice affected people of your protected characteristic.]
Your seemingly neutral practice discriminated against me indirectly.

Your practice of [explain the practice] placed me at a disadvantage because of my [insert relevant protected characteristic]. This is unlawful indirect discrimination.

[Add facts, explaining how the employer’s seemingly neutral policy or practice affected people of your protected characteristic.]
E, DS, DSy, DG, S, B
There has been a lack of empathy so that I feel bullied. This is discrimination.

There has been a lack of empathy for my situation to the extent that I feel bullied. This would amount to discrimination on the grounds of [insert protected characteristic].

[provide up to 3 bullet points of strong, recent examples - try to keep them within the last 2-3 months, if possible].
There was a lack of empathy so that I feel bullied. This is discrimination.

There was a lack of empathy for my situation to the extent that I felt bullied. This would amount to discrimination on the grounds of [insert protected characteristic].

[provide up to 3 bullet points of strong, recent examples - try to keep them within the last 2-3 months, if possible].
I have a physical or mental condition.
[As you’re aware,] I have [condition name(s)], which is a disability. [My absence from work on [dates] was caused by my disability.]
E, DS, DSy, DG, S, B
You didn't consider making reasonable adjustments for me.
You didn’t consider making reasonable adjustments for me, as required by the Equality Act 2010 [add detail if possible - what reasonable adjustments could’ve been helpful?].
Ethical veganism has been accepted by the employment tribunals as a form of protected belief.
Ethical veganism is a protected philosophical belief under the Equality Act 2010.
I've paid less for equal work because of my gender.

I've been paid less than a colleague for equal work. [ADD SPECIFIC DETAILS HERE.] Chapter 3 of the Equality Act 2010 implies an "equality clause" into every employment contract, which means that you have breached my contract. by paying me less than this colleague.

In addition, on [date] I was subject to sexual harassment at work in that [provide brief summary of sexual harassment]. This also contributed to my decision to resign and, were I to bring a claim at an Employment Tribunal, would result in higher compensation which would include an amount for injury to feelings.
E, DS, DSy, DG, S, B
Employment no longer tenable, but reserving position.
My continued employment may no longer be tenable. However, I’m reserving my position on this and whether to accept that your repudiatory breach of contract has constructively terminated my contract.

Your repudiatory breach of contract has made our client’s employment untenable. There is no affirmation of the breach of contract and our client reserve their right to resign and claim constructive unfair dismissal.
Haven't been provided with employment particulars in writing.

I have not been provided with a written statement of employment particulars. This is in breach of the employer's duty to provide an employee with a written statement of initial employment particulars pursuant to section 1 of the Employment Rights Act.

I requested an updated contract as the only contract in my possession was that dated [. ] when I joined the business. This was not issued at the time of request in February 2019, nor has it been issued subsequently, though I have been working in that position. This is a breach of the employer’s duty to provide the employee with a written statement of initial employment particulars or of any changes to their terms of employment.
Making me attend unsafe workplace is unlawful - constructive dismissal.

The business's insistence that I attend an unsafe work place was unlawful and constituted a fundamental breach of contract. I resigned in response to that, which amounts to unfair constructive dismissal.
I'm writing in relation to an unlawful deduction from my wages.
I am writing to you in relation to an unlawful deduction that has been made from my wages, as follows:

Clause [insert clause number] of my contract of employment provides that I be paid £ [insert £ amount] by way of [insert ONE of the following: salary OR bonus OR commission OR car allowance OR (insert other specified benefit)].
This amount is owed to me by custom and practice.

Custom and practice has created a contractual entitlement that I be paid [describe the entitlement, e.g. travel allowance or bonus]. The custom and practice is that [describe custom or practice, e.g. I was informed during my job interview in 2015 that I could expect to receive an annual bonus of 5% salary and every year since I joined the company all employees have received a 5% annual bonus.]. Under the contractual entitlement created by custom and practice I was entitled to be paid [£ insert amount].
You reduced my salary without my agreement.
You reduced my salary on [insert date] without my agreement.
Never agreed to reduction of salary.
You say I agreed in writing, however you have patently misinterpreted my words - I never agreed, and would not have agreed, to this reduction to my salary.

Pursuant to my contractual entitlement, I should have received this payment on [insert date]. The failure of [name of organisation] to make this payment represented a deduction of my wages, which I did not signify my agreement or consent to in writing, which would have been required for such a deduction to be lawfully made.
Payments became due and you failed to pay.

Pursuant to my contractual entitlement, payment of the following payments became due: [list sums and dates here]. The failure of [name of organisation] to make these payments represented a deduction of my wages, which I did not signify my agreement or consent to in writing, which would have been required for such a deduction to be lawfully made.
The unlawful deductions of my wages had a negative effect on me - please rectify them.

This unlawful deduction of my wages has [insert whichever of the following apply: 
-- negatively affected my confidence and mental health 
-- caused me stress
-- caused me financial hardship]. 
However, if the unlawful deduction of my wages is rectified within [insert number of days] I would not need to bring a claim in the Employment Tribunal seeking an order for payment, compensation and costs.
The unlawful deductions of my wages had a negative effect on me.

This unlawful deduction of my wages has [insert whichever of the following apply: 
-- negatively affected my confidence and mental health 
-- caused me stress
-- caused me financial hardship].
Intend to claim the difference between what was paid and owed to me.
I intend to claim payment of the difference between what you paid me and what I was contractually entitled to.
- payment of the difference between what you paid and what I was contractually entitled to.

Numerous weeks into my new role, I have still not received the salary specified in the confirmation letter. This amounts to an unlawful deduction of wages of around [  ] per month, over the course of [ ] months.
Unlawful deductions of wages are a breach of contract - entitled to resign and claim constructive dismissal.
These unlawful deductions fundamentally breach my contract of employment and would entitle me to resign and claim constructive dismissal in an employment tribunal.
I also refer to unlawful deductions from my wages /furlough payments (I'm still employed)

I also refer to unlawful deductions that have been made from my wages, specifically in relation to the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (furlough) payments, which as you’re aware are the employer’s responsibility.
Resigned because of unlawful deductions of wages - constructive dismissal.
These unlawful deductions fundamentally breach my contract of employment which is why I resigned and intend to claim constructive dismissal in an employment tribunal.
Gross misconduct - investigation and dismissal unfair.

As you’re no doubt aware, gross misconduct is a particularly serious allegation against an employee, and any resultant dismissal must follow a fair procedure and be fair in the circumstances. This includes investigating the matter properly and giving the employee a chance to respond. This wasn't done in my case.
Disciplinary process/action against me is unfair.

In the circumstances, the disciplinary process against me is unjustified and unfair, and any resulting disciplinary action would clearly be unfair. In particular: [add up to three bullet points with the strongest reasons that it is unfair. Examples: lack of evidence; that even if proven, the action wasn't misconduct; bias. Try to explain your reasons.]

I was told at the dismissal meeting that I was being dismissed due to poor performance. However, I believe that my [protected characteristic - if more than one include both/all] influenced your decision to dismiss me.
Dismissal because of performance was in fact discriminatory.

I was told at the dismissal meeting that I was being dismissed due to poor performance. However, I believe that my [protected characteristic - if more than one include both/all] influenced your decision to dismiss me, as [I told you] [you knew] [I was pregnant] [prior to the dismissal].
My performance didn't warrant performance management.

I don't believe that my performance warrants performance management due to the following reasons: 
[Add up to three short bullet points as to why you believe that. e.g. 
-- In my last appraisal I was told I exceeded all of my targets...
 --

I don't believe that my performance was poor because: 
[Add up to three short bullet points as to why you believe that. e.g.
-- In my last appraisal I was told I exceeded all of my targets...
-- 
--                                                                                                                      ]
You didn't follow a reasonable procedure before dismissing for poor performance.

You didn't follow a reasonable procedure, involving giving adequate warnings and opportunity to improve, before dismisssing me. [In particular ... add three bullet points.] 
The dismissal was therefore unfair.
My redundancy would be unfair as it doesn't comply with the law.

For an organisation to fairly dismiss an employee by reason of redundancy there has to be both a genuine redundancy situation (which is not necessarily admitted), and a fair redundancy process. A fair redundancy process must involve a period of consultation with the employee, which must be entered into with the employer having a genuinely open mind to redundancy being avoided taking into account any suggestions the employee may have as to how his redundancy might be avoided. If the employee leaving at the end of the consultation process had been predetermined then the dismissal will automatically be unfair. I do not believe you consulted fairly and took my suggestions into account during the redundancy process, and accordingly any redundancy dismissal would be unfair.

I believe that the redundancy package offered is inadequate and so I am considering bringing a claim at an employment tribunal, which would result in substantial damages for loss of earnings [and injury to feelings]. I would, however, prefer to remain on amicable terms, and resolving the matter now will save the company significant cost, time and stress in defending a claim it is likely to lose. If no resolution can be reached, I intend to proceed with my Employment Tribunal claim.
The current redundancy selection criteria are unfair [and discriminatory] because ... .

The factors or criteria used in the selection process are unfair [and discriminatory] because [set out your reasons for thinking that the factors or criteria used are unfair - provide up to 3 bullet point examples, starting with the strongest such as discrimination].  
[Examples:
-- 'The selection criteria include sickness absence which discriminates against me as I am disabled and have more sickness absences than other, non-disabled, colleagues';
-- 'The criteria target part time workers which discriminates against women;'
-- 'The criteria put people with childcare responsibilities at a disadvantage, which amounts to indirect discrimination on the grounds of sex and/or marriage or civil partnership';
-- 'I am being scored a 4 for Performance when all my appraisals have scored at least 6 for this criterion;'
-- 'My manager is scoring me lower than he should because he does not like me and these scores are not justified;'
-- 'The work I have done on [insert job/task details] has not been taken into account.']
The redundancy consultation isn't meaningful because ... .
If a meaningful consultation were to be carried out, I wouldn't be made redundant because ... .
Questioned reasons for my redundancy - answer concerned duplication of work ... .
I questioned the reasons for my redundancy. The answer I received concerned duplication of work, but you were not able to articulate [  ].
This shows that the selection process was predetermined.
This shows that the selection process was predetermined.

Suitable alternative employment was not considered when it should have been. Another job was advertised within the company with the same job title as mine, significant crossover in skills and responsibilities and salary but was not considered for me as ‘suitable alternative employment’.
I'm writing regarding the current redundancy process, which I believe to be unfair and discriminatory.
I am writing regarding the current redundancy process, which I believe to be unfair and discriminatory.
My redundancy was motivated by discrimination.
I believe my redundancy was motivated by my [protected characteristic], which is a protected characteristic under the Equality Act 2010. This is because: [Inset up to 3 bullet point reasons].
Redundancy selection criteria were unfair because ... .

The factors or criteria used in the selection process were unfair because [set out your reasons for thinking that the factors or criteria used were unfair]. [Examples of reasons include: 'the selection criteria included sickness absence which discriminated against me as I am disabled and had more sickness absences than other, non-disabled, colleagues'; 'the criteria targeted part time workers which discriminated against women.']
My redundacy is motivated by my age because ... .
It is clear that I was made redundant because of my age and therefore amounts to discrimination. This is because: [INSERT UP TO 3 BULLET POINT REASONS].
I have a disability  - choosing me for potential redundancy is discriminatory.

[As you're aware,] I have [name condition(s)]. This impairment is longterm and has a substantial effect on day-to-day activities and I have been absent from work for [  ] months because of this/these conditions. In these circumstances, the business's failure to help me return to work and to choose me for potential redundancy is unfavourable treatment due to something arising from a disability. [In addition, you could have made the following reasonable adjustments to help me return to work ... include if appropriate and up to three reasonable adjustments, in bullet points if you wish.]
No actual reduction in work - redundancy based on anticipation of losses only.

This is not a genuine redundancy situation as there hasn't been an actual reduction in the amount of the type of work that I do. Selecting me for redundancy is based on a speculative anticipation of losses only. Therefore, my dismissal would be unfair.

Anticipating [losses] doesn’t mean I’m redundant - there is still the same amount of work to be done, therefore I’m not being dismissed because of a reduction in the amount of the type of work I do. For this reason, this is not a genuine redundancy dismissal and and resulting dismissal will inevitably be unfair.
I refer to the current redundancy process and your proposal to make me redundant.

I refer to the redundancy process that we are currently going through, and in particular the business's proposal [to make me redundant] and/or [that I accept the alternative position as ...]. Please complete/delete as appropriate.
You're implementing the restructure in bad faith to remove me because ... .
No basis to dismiss me fairly on the ground of redundancy because ... .

There is no basis to dismiss me fairly on the ground of redundancy: my role still exists because [insert reasons why you believe your role still exists - see below for examples]]. [Examples: 'the purported new role of [insert name of new role] has all the same duties as my role but it has simply been renamed'; 'A colleague [insert name of person] has been told that they will be appointed to undertake the duties I perform, after I have left'.]
You're not using objective criteria in your redundancy selection process.
I do not believe that you are using objective criteria in your redundancy selection process.  If you were using such criteria, I would not be selected for redundancy.

There are [insert number] other people performing the same/similar role as me but you are not using any objective criteria or carrying out any selection process to determine which of us should be selected for redundancy. If you were to carry out such a selection process fairly, I would not be selected.
Should be selected for the new role.

The new role of [insert role title] contains a significant portion of my current duties and there should be a selection process to determine whether I or [insert name of other person] should be appointed to this role. If such a process were to be carried out fairly, I would be appointed to the role.
Not being consulted adequately on redundancy and because of this ... .
Not being given an opportunity to apply for alternative role.
My redundancy is unfair as it doesn't comply with the law.

For an organisation to fairly dismiss an employee by reason of redundancy there has to be both a genuine redundancy situation (which is not necessarily admitted), and a fair redundancy process. A fair redundancy process must involve a period of consultation with the employee, which must be entered into with the employer having a genuinely open mind to redundancy being avoided taking into account any suggestions the employee may have as to how his redundancy might be avoided. If the employee leaving at the end of the consultation process had been predetermined then the dismissal will automatically be unfair. I do not believe you consulted fairly and took my suggestions into account during the redundancy process, and accordingly my redundancy dismissal is unfair.
I'm writing about my recent redundancy, which was discriminatory.

This dismissal was unfair [and discriminatory]. I am now seeking resolution before lodging proceedings in the Employment Tribunal. Resolving the matter now will save the company significant cost in defending a claim. There will also be a significant saving in the management time that would be spent dealing with this issue. If no resolution can be reached I will proceed with my Employment Tribunal claim. The reasons my dismissal was unfair can be summarised as follows:
You were implementing the restructure in bad faith to remove me because ... .

There was no basis to dismiss me fairly on the ground of redundancy: my role still existed because [insert here the reasons why you believe your role still existed]. [Examples of reasons: 'the purported new role of [insert name of new role] had all the same duties as my role but it had simply been renamed'; 'A colleague [insert name of person] was told that they would be appointed to undertake the duties I performed, after I had left']
You didn't use objective redundancy selection criteria.
I do not believe that you used objective criteria in your redundancy selection process. If you had used such criteria, I would not have been selected for redundancy.
You didn't score me fairly for redundancy because ... .
Shouldn't have been selected for redundancy.

There were [insert number] other people performing the same/similar role as me but you did not use any objective criteria or carry out any selection process to determine which of us should be selected for redundancy. If you had carried out such a selection process fairly, I would not have been selected.
Should've been appointed to new role.

The new role of [insert role title] contained a significant portion of the duties I carried out before I was dismissed and there should have been a selection process to determine whether I should have been appointed to this role. If such a process had been carried out fairly, I would've been appointed to the role.
Wasn't consulted about redundancy and because of this ... .
If a meaningful consultation carried out, I wouldn't be redundant.
Should've been given opportunity to apply for an alternative role.

I was not given the opportunity to apply for [insert name of role]. I should have been appointed to the role which was a suitable alternative role for me because [Set out your reasons here, for example:  'I had the skills necessary to undertake this role'; 'I had already successfully carried out a similar role'; 'the role was very similar to my role which was made redundant].

I applied for the alternative role of [insert name of role] but was unsuccessful. I should have been appointed to this role as it was a suitable alternative role for me. There was no reasonable basis why I was not appointed because: [Insert your reasons here, eg: ‘I had the skills necessary to undertake this role'; 'I had already successfully carried out a similar role'; 'the role was very similar to my role which was made redundant’].
Didn't apply for the alternative role as was told I wouldn't be successful.

I didn't apply for the alternative role of [insert name of role] because it was made clear to me that I would not be fairly considered for it. I should have been appointed to the role as it was a suitable alternative role for me. There was no reasonable basis why I was not appointed to this role because: [Set out your reasons here, eg:  ‘I had the qualifications and skills needed’; ‘I had carried out a similar role before and had been successful in it’; the role was largely the same as my  role which was made redundant’].
Redundancy process was unfair - in fact dismissed because of my whistleblowing.

The redundancy process was unfair. I was in fact dismissed because of making a protected disclosure in respect of [add detail]. Such dismissal is unlawful under the Employment Rights Act 1996, as amended by the Public Interest Disclosure Act 1998. Due to the seriousness of the matter, I believe I would receive a high level of compensation if I brought a claim at the Employment Tribunal.
Redundancy process unfair - was in fact dismissed because of whistleblowing.

I've been dismissed unfairly, which gives me grounds to seek compensation in the employment tribunals. In particular, I believe the redundancy process was unfair and I was in fact dismissed because of whistleblowing.

My workload to be so excessive and stressful as to constitute a repudiatory breach of contract meaning that my resignation was unfair constructive dismissal. [In particular ... it could make your letter stronger if you list between one and three points showing how your employer treated you so badly. If just one bullet point, keep on this line. If more than one, we'd suggest bullet points beneath here.]
Bad treatment led to constructive dismissal.

Your treatment of me amounted to a fundamental breach of the implied term of trust and confidence in our employment agreement. Accordingly, my resignation was unfair constructive dismissal, and would entitle me to claim compensation in an employment tribunal. [In particular: add up to the three bullet points summarising the poor treatment.]
My suspension was a kneejerk reaction.

As you should know, an employer should never suspend an employee as a "kneejerk" reaction - it always requires a justification, whatever the allegation. No [adequate] reason was given to me as to why suspension was necessary. I consider my suspension to be a breach of the implied term of trust and confidence between the employer and employee [and discriminatory]. In the circumstances, I consider this to be a fundamental breach of contract and would be constructive dismissal were I to resign.  [In the circumstances, it is clear to me that I was suspended in bad faith for discriminatory reasons. In particular, 
[list up to 3 bullet points proving this, starting with the strongest.
-- e.g. I was suspended for discriminatory reasons because...;]
I refer to my suspension, which was discriminatory.
I refer to my suspension from work on [date] [and the ongoing [disciplinary / performance] (delete as appropriate) process], which I consider to be unjustified and discriminatory.
I refer to my suspension, which was discriminatory and due to whistleblowing.

I refer to my suspension from work on [date] [and the ongoing [disciplinary / performance] (delete as appropriate) process], which I consider to be unjustified, discriminatory and motivated by my whistleblowing.

I [also] have strong reasons to believe that such treatment is due to my whistleblowing, which is protected under the Employment Rights Act 1996, as amended by the Public Interest Disclosure Act 1998. As you know, I made [a] protected disclosure[s] in respect of [describe how you told your employer or relevant authority about xxx]. This concerns the company’s failure to comply with its legal obligations.
You didn't treat my whistleblowing seriously, despite the severity of the act concerned.
You didn't treat my protected disclosure seriously, despite the severity of the act concerned. [insert explanation why you think so]
Failure to deal with the whistleblowing issue to the severity warranted by the act committed
E, R, C, H, W, B

I have strong reasons to believe that such treatment is due to my whistleblowing, which is protected under the Employment Rights Act 1996, as amended by the Public Interest Disclosure Act 1998. As you know, I made [a] protected disclosure[s] in respect of [describe how you told your employer or relevant authority about xxx]. This concerns the company’s failure to comply with its legal obligations. The company’s disregard of its employees’ health and safety is particularly serious.
E, DS, DSy, DG, S, B

In addition, your lack of empathy could amount to a fundamental breach of the implied term of trust and confidence in our employment agreement. This would entitle me to resign and claim compensation for unfair constructive dismissal in the employment tribunal.
E, R, C, H, W, B
Situation cannot be resolved by grievance - my position untenable.

After consideration, I feel that all this cannot be resolved by informal or formal grievance and therefore my position is untenable. I would be prepared to enter into a settlement agreement, under which my employment would come to an end by agreement, on the following terms:
Entitled to resign and claim constructive dismissal.

It appears to me that some or all the matters raised could individually or collectively constitute a repudiatory breach of my contract of employment, which would entitle me to resign and claim compensation in the employment tribunals.
My employment no longer tenable, but reserving position.

As a result of this situation, I consider that my continued employment may no longer be tenable. However, I am reserving my position in relation to this, my rights under the company grievance procedure and ultimately whether to accept that the repudiatory breach situation has constructively terminated my contract.
Unfair redundancy process affecting my chances of staying employed - I want it remedied.
This unfair redundancy process is affecting my chances of remaining employed and I would like it to be remedied as soon as possible.
Redundancy unfair - I'm making a settlement offer.

This unfair redundancy has negatively affected my confidence and mental health and it is likely to be some time before I am able to find alternative employment.  In light of the losses I am likely to suffer, I am prepared to reach a settlement on the following terms:
Would like to stay employed but prepared to leave.

I have enjoyed this job, however I cannot continue working like this. Accordingly, I'd like to invite you to transfer me to another department. That would be my preferred solution.
 
If this is not an option, my continued employment may no longer be tenable. However, I am reserving my position in relation to this, my rights under the company grievance procedure and ultimately whether to accept that the repudiatory breach situation has constructively terminated my contract.
I'm considering bringing a claim (except for discrimination).
Accordingly, I am considering bringing a claim at an employment tribunal, which would result in substantial damages.
Our client is prepared to present an employment tribunal claim, which would result in substantial damages.
I also refer to unlawful deductions from my wages/furlough payments (I'm no longer employed)
I refer to unlawful deductions that were made from my wages, specifically in relation to the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (furlough) payments.
I refer to my resignation due to health and safety concerns.
I refer to my resignation on [ ], which was principally due to health and safety concerns at work.
Gross misconduct - allegations trivial, process unfair.

As you’re no doubt aware, gross misconduct is a particularly serious allegation against an employee. I was accused of [add detail]. That's clearly not misconduct, let alone gross misconduct. You then conducted unfair and biased disciplinary proceedings, without investigating the matter properly [and/or giving me a chance to respond/listening to my defence].
You failed to show flexibility when I requested an alternative date for redundancy interview.
You failed to show flexibility when I requested an alternative interview date due to an important prior commitment.
Failure to show priority to / flexibility to me when requesting alternative interview date.
Not applying for alternative role as was told I wouldn't be considered.
I am not applying for the alternative role of [insert name of role] because it has been made clear to me that I would not be fairly considered for it.

An employer should never suspend an employee as a "kneejerk" reaction - it always requires a justification, whatever the allegation. No [adequate] reason was given for my suspension. I consider my suspension to be a breach of the implied term of trust and confidence between the employer and employee [and discriminatory]. In the circumstances, I consider this to be a fundamental breach of contract and would be constructive dismissal were I to resign.
